name: Reverse Linked List II
title: Reverse Linked List II
content:
Given the head of a singly linked list and two integers left and right where left <= right, reverse the nodes of the list from position left to position right, and return the reversed list.

 

Example 1:

Input: head = [1,2,3,4,5], left = 2, right = 4
Output: [1,4,3,2,5]

Example 2:

Input: head = [5], left = 1, right = 1
Output: [5]

 

Constraints:

  • The number of nodes in the list is n.
  • 1 <= n <= 500
  • -500 <= Node.val <= 500
  • 1 <= left <= right <= n

 

Follow up: Could you do it in one pass?

discussion_posts.name: zeroand1only
discussion_posts.content: What the hell? so the Left and Right are 1-based POSITIONs, not node.val?  who the hell uses 1-based positions.

discussion_posts.name: ALS_Venky
discussion_posts.content:
So, this is a Linked list week.
By the way, `Happy Janmastami :)`

discussion_posts.name: sameer89
discussion_posts.content: Wasted so much time coding up the solution assuming that left and right are node values. Who would\'ve guessed they are indices (with 1 based indexing btw). And to confuse you even more they have come up with the most ambiguous first test case.

discussion_posts.name: pqow16
discussion_posts.content: This problem should explicitly state that it is 1-indexed

discussion_posts.name: DmitryPopov1988
discussion_posts.content: I spent maybe 3 hours to solve this problem. Sometimes I think that I am stupid (:

discussion_posts.name: rajharshyadav2
MushyBear
discussion_posts.content: Who writes these discriptions and examples? The left and right are indices, not node.vals... wouldve been great to know before wasting my time.

discussion_posts.name: zhizhipaint
uzia35
discussion_posts.content: I think the first example is confusing people, it should probably have different numbers, left and right being numbers would make this question much harder if you had to account for duplicates with no constraints specifying so.
